PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [x] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

Separated from #18882 

- [x] depends on: #20268

### PR summary [65ef3da46b](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20143/commits/65ef3da46bd3485a827390373323a76172c02038)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ contract_C`
`+ contract_add`
`+ contract_mul_expand`
`+ expand_dvd`
`+ isCoprime_expand_iff`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Anyone knows why there's a build error?
```
âœ– [5536/5789] Building Mathlib.RingTheory.Localization.Integral
trace: .> LEAN_PATH=././.lake/packages/Cli/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/batteries/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/Qq/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/aesop/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/proofwidgets/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/importGraph/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/LeanSearchClient/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/plausible/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/build/lib LD_LIBRARY_PATH=././.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/plausible/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/LeanSearchClient/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/importGraph/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/proofwidgets/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/aesop/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/Qq/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/batteries/.lake/build/lib:././.lake/packages/Cli/.lake/build/lib:/home/lean/.elan/toolchains/leanprover--lean4---v4.15.0-rc1/lib/lean:/home/lean/.elan/toolchains/leanprover--lean4---v4.15.0-rc1/lib /home/lean/.elan/toolchains/leanprover--lean4---v4.15.0-rc1/bin/lean -Dpp.unicode.fun=true -DautoImplicit=false -Dweak.linter.docPrime=true -Dweak.linter.hashCommand=true -Dweak.linter.oldObtain=true -Dweak.linter.refine=true -Dweak.linter.style.cdot=true -Dweak.linter.style.dollarSyntax=true -Dweak.linter.style.header=true -Dweak.linter.style.lambdaSyntax=true -Dweak.linter.style.longLine=true -Dweak.linter.style.longFile=1500 -Dweak.linter.style.missingEnd=true -Dweak.linter.style.multiGoal=true -Dweak.linter.style.setOption=true ././././Mathlib/RingTheory/Localization/Integral.lean -R ./././. -o ././.lake/build/lib/Mathlib/RingTheory/Localization/Integral.olean -i ././.lake/build/lib/Mathlib/RingTheory/Localization/Integral.ilean -c ././.lake/build/ir/Mathlib/RingTheory/Localization/Integral.c --json
error: ././././Mathlib/RingTheory/Localization/Integral.lean:321:8: ambiguous, possible interpretations 
  _root_.map_eq_zero (algebraMap K L) : (algebraMap K L) ?m.157807 = 0 â†” ?m.157807 = 0
  
  Polynomial.map_eq_zero (algebraMap K L) : Polynomial.map (algebraMap K L) ?m.158624 = 0 â†” ?m.158624 = 0
error: Lean exited with code 1
Some required builds logged failures:
- Mathlib.RingTheory.Localization.Integral
error: build failed
Running linter on specified module: Mathlib
uncaught exception: object file '././.lake/build/lib/Mathlib.olean' of module Mathlib does not exist
Error: The process '/usr/bin/env' failed with exit code 1
```
`map_eq_zero` is now ambiguous with `Polynomial.map_eq_zero` when `Polynomial` is open. Here I would suggest marking `Polynomial.map_eq_zero` as `protected`

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#20268~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

LGTM!
Maybe @YaelDillies could call maintainer merge?

```suggestion
@[gcongr]
theorem expand_dvd {a b : R[X]} (p : â„•) (h : a âˆ£ b) : expand R p a âˆ£ expand R p b := by
```

```suggestion
theorem isCoprime_of_expand {a b : k[X]} {n : â„•} (hn : n â‰  0) :
```
Could you please make this change in a separate PR?
Added! #20268
This increases the imports to quite a few files. Do you think you could reorder things around so as to remove this import increase?
Maybe I didn't get your question - reorder which things?
Move lemmas across files is what I mean

I have to admit I also don't follow what the 'import increase' means exactly.

Right now the only new import line is line 8 'import Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.FieldDivision'.
Are you suggesting that we can move the lemmas in `Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.FieldDivision` to other existing imports, and delete line 8?

((I'll be happy with a brief yes/no answer Yael. Your wrist is more important than this)

I don't actually know what the answer is here, but I expect it to be one of:
* Move the new lemmas to another existing file
* Create a new file for the new lemmas

As a general rule, since this statement doesn't require DecidableEq, you should remove that assumption and use `classical` within the proof instead.
But I have been able to prove this without using gcd or importing FieldDivision at [this branch](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/a93a6be64d717035bedf898c18688df651c2ec53). Feel free to merge! The reason that `contract_mul_expand` works is because the polynomial algebra is Z/pZ-graded, but I'm not sure if we want to introduced a GradedAlgebra instance on Polynomial.
That's great! If you don't mind, maybe you can add your proof to this PR yourself to make sure that you take the contribution for it.
Merging Junyan's branch into here will show their contribution ðŸ˜‰
I just merged Junyan's branch via GitHub. I do not know if his contribution is represented properly by doing this; feel free to revert if it's not the case.
Thanks! Looks good, my avatar is shown on the commits.

Empirically, explicit arguments are only really useful for rewriting lemmas, which this one is not
```suggestion
theorem expand_dvd {a b : R[X]} {p : â„•} (h : a âˆ£ b) : expand R p a âˆ£ expand R p b := by
```

I would expect the explicit argument to be useful for `have := expand_dvd p h` or `obtain`. On the other hand, for rewriting lemmas I'd usually keep arguments appearing on both sides implicit, since they are not needed most of the time when using `rw` and making them implicit saves some underscores (or even parentheses) when you occasionally use the lemmas in term mode. Can you explain your rationale (or post a link to your explanation if you've done it before)?

It's possibly an artifact of my style but here are some arguments:
1. Non-rewriting lemmas are almost always used in a context where there's enough information for Lean to infer them by unification.
2. In the rare cases where there isn't enough info, it usually means you should add a type ascription for your reader to understand, which is better than filling in an argument of unclear purpose. Eg I would consider `obtain âŸ¨q, hqâŸ© : expand R p a âˆ£ expand R p b := expand_dvd h` better style than `obtain âŸ¨q, hqâŸ© := expand_dvd p h`.
3. Non-rewriting lemmas are very likely to be used in proof terms, where extra underscores and brackets are painful.
4. Rewriting lemmas are almost always used with `rw`, where extra explicit arguments don't hurt when unnecessary and come in handy when needed to disambiguate between several occurrences.
5. If you're trying to use a rewriting lemma in term mode, then probably you should be making a `calc` block instead.

Thanks for the detailed explanations!
I agree that variables appearing in the conclusion of non-rewriting lemmas can be made implicit. Explicit arguments in rewriting lemmas for disambiguation is also a good point. Regarding point 5, what do you think about the many uses of an iff lemma concatenated with `.trans` in [these search results](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Aleanprover-community%2Fmathlib4%20iff.trans&type=code)? I don't think these should be made calc blocks.

For this particular lemma, I realize we don't need it as it's a special case of `_root_.map_dvd`.

Ah yes sorry, I forgot to mention but I do consider iff lemmas separately because of this precise issue. Arguments to iff lemmas should almost always be implicit. The only exception that comes to mind is when a variable appears on the LHS of the iff, but not on the RHS. This happens pretty rarely

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem contract_C (r : R) : contract p (C r) = C r := by simp [contract]
```

```suggestion
theorem contract_add {p : â„•} (hp : p â‰  0) (f g : R[X]) :
```

```suggestion
theorem contract_mul_expand {p : â„•} (hp : p â‰  0) (f g : R[X]) :
```
Why is this false when `p = 0`? What does each side simplify to?
`extract 0` sends `f0 + f1 X + f2 X^2 + ... + fn X^n` (with `fn` nonzero) to `f0 (1 + X + X^2 + ... + X^n)`.
Is this not an iff?
Good catch!

```suggestion
```

pullRequest.title: feat: Two lemmas on divisibility and coprimality of `expand`
